awd_titl_txt: DIP: ScienceKit for ScienceEverywhere - A Seamless Scientizing Ecosystem for Raising Scientifically-Minded Children
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that will help in envisioning the next generation of learning technologies and advancing what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. Development and Implementation (DIP) Projects build on proof-of-concept work that showed the possibilities of the proposed new type of learning technology, and project teams build and refine a minimally-viable example of their proposed innovation that allows them to understand how such technology should be designed and used in the future and answer questions about how people learn with technology. Although for years researchers have believed technology could afford anytime-anywhere learning, we still don't understand how learners behave differently across contexts, such as home, school, and in the community, and how to get youth to identify as learners across those contexts. This proposal aims to use mobile devices and strategically placed shared kiosks to 'scientize' youth in two low-income communities. Through strategic partnerships with community organizations, educators, and families, the innovation is to get primary and middle-school students engaging in scientific inquiry in the context of their neighborhoods. Research will help determine how the technology can best be deployed, but also answer important questions about how communities can provide support to help kids think like scientists and identify with science.

This project will design and implement ubiquitous technology
tools that include mobile social media and tangible, community displays (collectively called ScienceKit) that are deeply embedded into two urban neighborhoods, and demonstrate how such ubiquitous technologies and related cyberlearning strategies are vital to improve information flow and coordination across a neighborhood ecosystem, in order to create environments where children can connect their science learning across contexts and time (e.g. scientizing). A program called ScienceEverywhere comprised of partnerships between tightly connected neighborhood organizations with mentors, teachers, parents, and researchers will help learners develop scientifically literate practices both in and out of school, and will demonstrate students' learning to their communities. Research will consist of mixed methods studies of use of the tools, including iterative design-based research, ethnography, and the use of participant observers from the community; these will be triangulated with usage logs of the technologies and content analysis of microblogs by the learners on their identities and interests. Discourse analysis of interviews with focal learners will orient the qualitative work on identity development, and analysis using activity theory will inform the influences of the social practices and sociotechnical systems on learner trajectories. Formative evaluation will help shed light on if and how the sociotechnical system promotes STEM literacy and STEM identity development.

por.por_cntn:
ScienceKit for Science Everywhere is an NSF-funded project focused on designing community-based technologies and learning experiences to help youth in resource-constrained communities connect STEM learning across neighborhood (i.e., home, school, community) settings. Our overarching research aim has been to understand how we can design community-driven technologies and life-relevant learning experiences so that entire neighborhoods can recognize science in their everyday lives and take up new opportunities to engage in science relevant to their communities. Grounded in asset-based community development and disposition development frameworks, our approach sought specifically to build on existing resources within communities and deeply engage youth, educators, and community mentors in the design of the Science Everywhere technology and learning experiences. Our findings have contributed new understandings of disposition development within resource-constrained community contexts [IDC 2018], new approaches for participatory design with communities [CHI 2016], and has led to new insights related to community infrastructure to facilitate STEM learning [CHI 2018, ICLS 2018].

 

During the funding award period, we designed, built, and studied the Science Everywhere technology and integrated learning experiences, which included:

 

  • A mobile social media app that allowed youth and adult community members to capture and share science learning experiences across contexts with photos, text, and polls and to engage socially with one another’s posts to spur, encourage, and enhance science practice.
  • Ubiquitous community displays that were placed in several community settings, enabling children and adults in the community to scroll through posts made through the app and give curious, insightful, and investigator badges to recognize the everyday science shared by youth.
  • Science in everyday life learning experiences for informal and formal learning settings to help youth and community mentors recognize STEM in their daily life activities (e.g., cooking, Minecraft) and community settings (e.g., environmental stewardship of local streams).

 

We developed these tools and experiences using a design method called participatory design, which engaged youth, community organizers, teachers, parents, and adult mentors directly in our design process. We studied the implementation of this socio-technical system in two metropolitan, resource-constrained neighborhoods for over five years, working with over 370 youth and 155 adult participants in both formal and informal learning environments (i.e., middle school science classrooms, afterschool, and summer programs). Below, we summarize our key achievements.

 

Key Achievements

  • Our work has contributed methods and techniques for doing participatory design across multiple stakeholders including children, teachers, and informal educators. Analyses such as the one presented in our CHI 2016 paper contribute an understanding of ways in which design processes evolve as we work with families over time. Our CHI 2018 publication considers design ideas from a range of community stakeholders (i.e., children, teachers, church volunteers/members, etc.).
  • Our work has contributed to our understanding of ways mobile computing, social media, and tangible displays can be designed and used to promote learning between multiple stakeholders (e.g., youth, parents, teachers, informal educators). A key contribution in our CHI 2018 submission was a study of large tangible displays specifically oriented towards promoting learning.
  • Our work has contributed an understanding of ways youth’s interactions with community-based social media sharing technologies can support their connections between STEM learning and everyday life, specifically enabling them to integrate their own interests, social experiences, and culture into science learning [IDC 2018; C-CHI 2018]. Additionally, our work has illuminated the different ways science learning is enacted with such technical supports across different community settings [ICLS 2018], an analysis which won a best student paper award.
  • Our work has contributed to our understanding of ways to support families in learning endeavors and highlights specific adult dispositions that foster scientizing in communities [AERJ, in Submission].
  • We have presented our findings to Citizen Science audiences who were interested in ways to broaden participation in citizen science efforts, particularly among minoritized and under-resourced communities.
  • We have presented our findings to Computer Science Education audiences who were interested in ways to broaden participation in computing through community-based learning experiences. Additionally, we presented findings from the Science Everywhere community program related to a new approach to engage youth in programming experiences, specifically having them construct physical mazes that motivate programming experiences.
  • PIs Clegg, Yip, and Ahn involved and mentored a diverse set of students undergraduate and graduate students from College of Information Studies, and the College of Education. Of the 15 student collaborators, seven were underrepresented minorities and six were female.
